div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South, and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Suez about November 1
R.M.S "Omrah" will leave Suez about November 15
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Port Said Oct 21
R.M.S. "Orient" will leave Port Said November 4

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Suez about October 24th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, will leave Port Said about October 27th.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangoon £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.

p.hi: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and COSTANTINOPLE, In connection with the Oriental Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS, AND LONDON.

div.p: S.S.Osmanieh,
Wednesday 4 p.m. Sept. 18October 2 October 16October 30
S.S.Ismailla
Wednesday 4 p.m. Sept. 11Sept. 25 October 9October 23
PALESTINE-SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaieh leave Alexandria alternatively on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damasous) Tripolf, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.
SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.
The mail steamers Dakahlleh and Kosseir leave Sueg alternatively on Wednesday at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK and Son (Egypt) Ltd. Hamburg-Amerika Reise-Bureau or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from Hamburg; weekly from Antwerp: every 4 weeks from Bordeaux direct to Alexandria; homewards every 2 weeks from Alexandria for Rotterdam and Hamburg, Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Lading to Alexandria, Cairo, Syria, etc. Special facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns.
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. "Samos" October 16th from Hamburgbound for Beyrouth.
S.S. "Delos" October 20th from Antwerpbound for RotterndamandHamburg.
S.S. "Chios" now in port discharging.
For tarif and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria Agent.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Khephren now on the berth, will sail on or about Wednesday 16th October, to be followed by S.S. Menepthah
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo.
For particulars appply R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for ALGIERS and LONDON or LIVERPOOL.
SALOON FARE £12. Special Summer season rates £10 Port Said to Marseilles £7.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 will leave PORT SAID about 2nd Nov. for Marseilles and Liverpool.
Due in London or Liverpool in 13 days.
The Saloon accomodation is amidships, and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Light, have all the latest improvements. For further information apply to the Company's Agents.
WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. Shipyard for construction of sternwheel steamers, barges, stream, motor launches, etc. Contractors for supply and erection of all classes of machinery, buildings, irrigation pumps, etc.

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special combined rall and steamer Nile Tours at greatly reduced prices.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country!

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d'Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 2833731-3-908

div.head: Austrian Lloyd
div.p: Weekly Mail Steamers from Alexandria to Brindisi Trieste (Venice) leaving Saturdays at 4 p.m. having connection in Brindisi with the Expres train on Tuesday morning to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London. Arrival at Trieste on Wednesday about 11 a.m. A Train de Luxe leave the same evening, 5.36 p.m. for Vienna, Frankfort Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London on Friday 5.12 p.m.
Weekly Intermediate Steamers from Alexandria to Trieste via Brindisi leave Alexandria every Thursday at 10 a.m.

p.hi: N.B.-Subject to alteration without responsibility for the regular service in case of quarantine.

div.head: Hoff's Malt HOMAX
div.p: Ideal Food Beverage for Convalescents
and all who highly tax their strength in a hot climate, through strenuous work or sporting life.
Practically non-alcoholic
Homax is a delicious tonic.
Homax creates appetite.
Homax digests food.
Homax invigorates the nervous.
SOLE MANUFACTURER-
M. HOFF, Hamburg, Germany.
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper
Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1907..

div.head: MACEDONIA AND THE BALKANS.
div.p: The "Morning Post" publishes the following survey of the conditions prevailing in Macedonia and the Balkan states :

Signs are not wanting that during the winter the Powers will have to keep anxious. watch over events in the Balkan peninsula. The report of the death of two Servian ex officers in a prison at Belgrade evidently discloses very ugly business indeed. The two men were anti-regicides, one of them vers outspoken. The report telegraphed roads like * fiction, covering a murder by the persons in authority. This is a grave matter. There was in Sorvin very strong resentment against the regicides, and the fact that King Peter did not see his way completely to dissociate himself from them has prevented his acquiring the heartfelt allegiance of the people of Servia. There has already been too much persecution of anti-regicides, and this new event cannot but arouse the feelings that have been smoulder ing, but have never been extinguished, against the murderers of King Alexander and minst I those who have profited by their crime. No one. knows this better than King Peter, who therefore feels himself weak when what the country needs is a raler firm enough in his sent to have a clear pólioy. The King, looking round for a 'stay, may hope to find it in Austria, and may therefore adopt what has hitherto been regarded as the anti-national policy of a pact with Austria, a coarse to which he may be the more easily impelled because the commercial campaign waged by Austria for the purpose of reducing Servia to submission inflicts real in convenience upon the inhabitants of Servia. The misfortune of Servia, is not to have a statesman on the European level who can take a broad view of affairs and see Europe as a whole, looking at something larger than the cliques at Belgrade. For Servis has great prog: pects that may be realised by patient. The time must come when a King of Servis may be able to make his bargain with statesmen of Vienna, but will come only to a Service that can wait as well as watch.

In Bulgaria things are not altogether healthy. The Ministry has gone too far in the direction of repression, reaction, and ChanI vinism. To have dismissed all the University professors, to have trumped up a ridiculous Lawsuit against one of Bulgaria's best states. men because he is rich, and to have given free rein to the Anti Hellenic passions that produced riots and outrages in various parts of the country and have driven thousands of Greeks out of the land is to have proclaimed to Europe that the Bulgarian Ministers are not of the class from which Europe expecta statesmen to be drawn. The best reply to the incursions of Greek bands into Macedonia would have been for the Bulgarian Government scrupulously to have protected the Greeks living in Bulgarin. Neither Bulgariang nor Servians seem to have fully realised that the autonomies of all the Balkan States are interdependent. If one of thein is absorbed by a Great Power the others are doomed, for none of them is strong enough to stand alone, least of all Bulgaris. The Greek states non are remarkable for intellectual shrewdness and even for their liberal education. Bat they are one and all infected with the tradition of an exaggerated Hellenism. Ever looking back to the past they cannot reconcile themselves to the realities of the modern world. It is trite that Pericles Athens was the home of an intellectual and spiritual life richer than has ever been known since. It is true that Alexander spread over the whole Fast a cul. tare derived from the best of what Greece bad until then produced. But the Athens of Pericles and the Empire of Alexander did not exist together, and could not have done. To-day neither the one nor the other is possible, but the modern Greeks dream of reproducing both at once, and over their dream they lose their chances of obtaining what is possible. To have attacked Turkey in the epoch of M. Delyannis would have been a fine thing if there had been in the Greek troops the spirit of Leonidas and his Three Hundred; but to have attacked Turkey and then to retreat without serious loss of life was farcical. The Greeks have to learn courage and political temperance. Instead of attempting this they are permitting their bands to commit outrages in Macedonia. Their excuse is that the Bulgarians began it. It is the exense of barbarians, and is unworthy of Hellenism in the sense in which Hellenism has any value or meaning to Europe. For the Hellenism which takes Europeans to Greece, for which Byron died and of which Shelley sang, meant the humanities in their best expression. While Servia.is on the verge of anarchy, Balgaria in the hands of reactionaries, and Greece given over to a spirit of barbarism, Roumania under the firm and judicious guid. ance of M. Stourdza is endeavouring to heal the wounds created by the agrarian rising of the spring. Roumania alone of th four States has the advantage of men who stand on the European level both in character and in intelligence. She needs them, for the stratification of her society is a danger, and her rich absentee landlords, superimposed on a peasant population living in conditions as bad as those of the West of Ireland twenty years ago, furnish a problem hard enough to test the powers of any statesman, however capable. The Turkish Empire, the neighbour of these smaller States, is also in a condition that causes some anxiety. The Sultan, able, car-seeing, and determined, has made himself the representative of the reaction against European influence. He has carried out with perseverance and without being hampered by any consideration the policy of restoring to his Empire, particularly in Asia, its Mohammedan and Turkish character. He has strengthened his Army. But in doing these things he has found himself unable either to lighten the burden of taxation or the system of espionage, and these two concomitants of his policy have estranged his subjects from it.

In these conditions of the neighbouring lands theory of injured humanity from Macedonia reaches the Great Powers. It is a piercing, a terrible cry, but its tones are dimmed by distance Many voices join in its confusing sound. There was at first the call of the rayah for just law and upright administration ; for safety of life and limb and of honour, and for the elementary rights of human beings. Then came the wails of those whoses homes were burned, and their kith and kin murdered, bither by bands or the irregulars who were supposed to chase them. There was an author. itative anarchy in which Bulgarians killed Turks And Greeks, and Tarks, Greeks, and Servants killed Bulgarians. The Powers intend that all this shall cease and that lite and property shall be safe in Macedonia. But the reforms have been obstructed and progress been too slow, so that there is as yet no guarantee against fresh troubles that may spread over the whole peninsula.

div.head: Survey of Nubia.
div.p: We learn that the Survey Department has commenced the work of making an archaeological survey of Nubia.

div.head: The "Mahroussa".
div.p: The Khedivial yacht "Mahroussa" left the Gabbary Graving Dock this morning after having been thoroughly overhauled,

div.head: The National Bank.
div.p: The construction of a new-building in Stamboul street for the Alexandria agency of the National Bank is to be commenced next week.

div.head: Austrian Medical Congress.
div.p: The Austrian Government has invited the Egyptian Government to send a delegate to the medical congress to be held at Budapest next April.

div.head: Mines Department.
div.p: Contrary to the reports current during the past few months, the Mines Department is to be continued and will, therefore, figure in the forthcoming budget.

div.head: St. Andrew's Church, Cairo.
div.p: We understand, that Mr. W. Wilson Pash, of the Egyptian General Mission, will conduct the first service of the season to-morrow morning at half past ten.

div.head: Alexandria Criminal Court.
div.p: The cases of the Ports and Lights Administration will be heard by the criminal court on Monday and it is expected that the hearing will extend over three sittings.

div.head: Commercial Conventions.
div.p: The commercial convention between Egypt and Servia will not come into force until the end of next year. The convention between this country and Roumanian will be signed on the return of the Roumanian consul-general.

div.head: The Inniskilling Fusiliers.
div.p: The 2nd Bat. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, at present quartered at the Kasr-el-Nil Barracks, are leaving in the course of a few days for Alexandria, where they will remain for three months prior to returning to Dublin.

div.head: Theft of Plate.
div.p: The Commandant of Police on visiting a bric a brac shop in the Hamzawi on Thursday, discovered a quantity of plate bearing the name of the Grand Continental Hotel. The owner of the shop was promptly arrested and an investigation is being made.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and October 10-1,011,971 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 555,206 tons were Welsh 124,299 Newcastle, 155,754 Yorkshire, 86,492 Scotch and 90,220 other qualities. During the corres- ponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 1,012,663.

div.head: The Cairo "Almshouses."
div.p: There is a persistent rumour in Cairo, for which no confirmation is, however, available, that Sir Vincent Corbett's very original scheme for providing houses for higher officials is not regarded with much favour by the new régime. It is said that the Government may eventually dispose of this property.

div.head: Surveying the Desert.
div.p: Mr. Ball, of the Survey Department, left Cairo on Thursday night for Upper Egypt, where he will complete the work begun last season, of making a topographical and a geographical survey of the south eastern portion of the desert lying to the north of the Sudan boundary, to Lat. 20, where his work will join with the Sudan survey which has already been made.

div.head: Calro Medioal School.
div.p: The following students of the Kasr el Aini School have qualified as doctors of medicine :-Anis Onsi, Ibrahim Fahmy, Fonad Sidky, Mohamed Sobhy, Mohamed Waly, Shaker Boulos, Mohamed, Fam Beshay, Nassif Tadros, Selim Ibrahim, Rizkalla Bersoum, Mohamed Maaz, Zeki Siddik, Sayed Abdelhamid, Mahmoud Zeki, Sayed Shoudry, Nasser Nabeeh and Hafez Afifi.

div.head: Cairo Theatrical Season.
div.p: On the 12th November next a new the atrical troupe having at their head the wellknown comédienne Mlle Suzanne Monte will commence a season in the Garden Theatre In the repertoire are the following.

"Demi-Vierges," "Vertige," "Adrienne Lecouvreur,' "Voleur," "Bonheur Mesdames," "Viveur," Zaza" and very probably the new play by Abel Hermant, performed at the Athenée. At the end of March we shall have the pleasure of greeting in the Abbas Theatre M. Leloir, a brilliant actor, who will produce. "Aventurière," "Rantzav," "Un père prodigue," "l'Avare," "le Courrier de Lyon," "Don Quichotte," "La Griffe."

div.head: RAS EL TIN SCHOOL.
div.p: Mr. Hicks, of Ras-el-Tin School, has resigned his appointment in order to take up, a position in the Grammar School at Leeds. Mr. Davies, of Ras-el-Tin School, has resigned and is not returning to Egypt. Mr. Jones, of Jesus College, Oxford, and Mr. Powell, of Keble College, Oxford, have arrived at Alexandria in order to join the professional staff of Ras-el-Tin School.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss Liner "Seti" sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool via Malta, with pas sengers, mails and general cargo; including 6,029 bales of cotton,

div.head: BLUNT'S SECRET HISTORY.
div.p: SIR E MALET'S CONTRADICTION.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Saturday.

Sir Edward Malet, who has just recovered from a long illness, writes to the "Times" controverting Sir Wilfred Blunt's statement, in his "Secret History of the Occupation of Egypt" that he was removed from his post by the Government during Arabi's rebeillon. His fever was the result of a plot to poison him and cause his removal to the steamer "Mongolia".

div.head: GOLD FOR EGYPT.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
LONDON, Saturday.
£700,000 in gold are leaving for Egypt to-
day.

div.head: THE S.S. "LUSITANIA."
div.p: ALL RECORDS BROKEN.
25.7 KNOTS PER HOUR.
The Cunard turbine S

The Cunard turbine S.S. "Lusitania" has broken all previous records across the Atlantic. A private telegram says that she arrived at New York at 1.17 a.m. yesterday, thus having made the passage from Liverpool in 4 days, 19 hours, and 52 minutes. Her speed during the voyage averaged 24:002 knots and she made a day's run of 617 knots, or 25.7 knots per hour.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
div.p: POLITICS & LAW.
"Al Watan" says:-

The students of the School of Law have again made a demonstration in honour of Mustafa Pasha Kamel, the avowed enemy of their Government which is giving them the plums of the Civil Service and entrusting them with the most important work of maintaining public security and repressing crime. When will the Government awake to a sense of their duty and put a stop to this scandalous state of affairs?

div.head: THE PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
div.p: The newly-formed Party of the People is the subject of unceasing criticism in the Nationalist Press. The reason of this outcry appears to be due to professional jealousy as when "Al Guerida" represented no particular group in politics it counted for nothing. Now, however, that it is the recognised organ of the "Party" it has become suddenly a paper of some importance and will have to be reckoned with by its vernacular confrères. "Al Moayad" in an article on this subject remarks:-

We acknowledge that among the members of the "Party of the People" there are some who are animated with sincere sentiments and noble principles, and who have only attached themselves to this party because they are convinced that they will render great services. thereby to their country. There are others who have attained high posts and who are men of clear consciences and whose assistance has been asked for, as their credit always strengthens political parties. There are also among them some influential young men with a great future before them. But, and nobody will gainsay the fact, among this swarm of persons some individuals have introduced themselves who only want to flatter those who hold the reins of Government, for the main object of the foundation of "Al Guerida", was to oppose the Nationalist Press. Others have been gained over because they have been ashamed to refuse to join the party, while others have been recruited by the wiles of partisans..

div.head: EGYPT AND INDIA.
div.p: ONE DOMINION.

German politicians are still eagerly speculating on the ultimate reasons for the conclusion of the Convention between England and Russia, and they are evidently convinced that some understanding has been arrived at be- tween the two nations which does not appear in the text of the Convention. Professor Hans Delbrück's opinion, expressed in the "Preussische Jahrbucher," is that "what the English have conceded is a mere bagatelle to what they have gained, which, in so far as agreements. signify anything, is of supreme value to them." If, he continues, the Ameer of Afghanistan remains an English vassal, a rampart is raised for the protection of India which will be scaled with difficulty, and the dominion secured over Southern Persia is another step towards the union of Egypt and India under one dominion. How could Russia enter into such an Agreement? he asks, and suggests a new solution, to the problem, namely, that Russia hopes thereby to induce the English Money Market to take up a new Russian Loan.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: The first party of the 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers to leave Alexandria for Khartoum will depart to-morrow morning at 5 o'clock from Sidi Gaber Station under the command of Major Featherstonehaugh. The battalion will leave in four parties.
The Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, who will relieve the Dublins here will arrive in four
similar parties.
The detachment of the 1st Kings Royal Rifles will leave Ras-el-Tin Camp for Cairo on the 28th inst. under the command of Major Robertson-Eustace, D.S.O.

div.head: EGYPT AND BELGIUM.
div.p: BARON DE GAIFFIER'S REPORT.
A MASTERLY REVIEW.

The "Recueil Consulaire Belge" recently published the report of Baron de Gaiffier d'Hestroy, Belgian Minister at Cairo, on the economie and commercial situation of Egypt in 1907. Particular interest is attached to this report as it gives a very accurate review of the Egyptian situation at the moment when the recent financial difficulties became crucial, that is to say when, considering the general discomfiture, everybody was asking where it was going to end.

It is, moreover, the first official document dealing with the prime factors of the actual period published by one of the commercial Powers largely represented by an ever-increasing import trade, and as such it also takes an important place among those documents, written or yet to be written, which might well be termed the bibliography of the financial crisis of 1907.

"Egypt," says the Baron, "from an import point of view, offers to the producers of all countries an incomparable market, the extent of which our manufacturers still seem to be unaware of, if one judges by the little which they accomplish. To-day the principal imports to Egypt are iron, steel, fuel, cereals, and manufactured products from the most common to the rarest, and these will always be on the increase for many reasons, the principal two of which are that local industry developes slowly, while the country greatly increases in wealth, thanks to the wise administration which was established twenty-five years ago."

In the course of his study the Belgian Minister reviews successively the existing industries of the country. He then deals with the causes of the increasing wealth of the country, the special climatic conditions, the continuous extension of the cultivated area of land, the favourable financial situation, the uninterrupted increase of imports and exports, and he remarks that the considerable increase during the last few years in the number of banks and the business done by these credit establishments is another indication, no less important, of the activity and commercial prosperity of the country. Speaking of the new companies Baron de Gaffier remarks that "the rapidly increasing wealth of the country and especially the formidable increase in the price of land have created alongside the banks a crowd of companies. During the year 1905 there were formed thirty new companies and ten founded companies increased their capitals. In 1906, the progress was still more rapid, and according to the documents which I have before me the number of new companies exceeded 47. At the end of 1906. and at the commencement of the present year we witnessed a veritable debauchery of shares." Turning to the question of land speculations, the Belgian Minister considers that the success of the newly created quarters is difficult to foretell and will depend especially upon the means of communication granted, rather than on their distance from town, and also on the public works and the manner in which they will be laid out.

Again-"During the period of speculation one did not buy to build, but to sell again. The great majority of buildings was previous to this movement. They do not answer to the needs of the moment and to the invested capitals. The increase in rents could not compensate the bad utilisation of the plots of land, and yet is not it of importance that by such means those who had building land greatly depreciated it, the proprietors of bare lands, and they are legion,' finding themselves possessors of dead bodies? The proprietors who have, or will have, the means to endow their lands with houses in accordance with the new conditions will have nothing to fear. Others who involved themselves in the movement in the hope of re-selling are exposed to cruel disappointments." Nevertheless "should they be subjected to prosecations, forced sales, and even in some cases to ruin, that can in no way affect the economic situation of the country."

It is certainly most encouraging to read so hopeful a view from one so well qualified to express an opinion, for it is but another symptom that in high circles the present crisis is not considered as having affected to any degree the roots of the real prosperity of the country, and it is, moreover, only by such declarations that one can really reassure European public opinion, especially from the commercial and financial point of view on the future lot of Egypt, which one is only too pleased in Europe to compare with that of the Argentine Republic.

The report also deals with Belgian companies and contracts, with Egypt as a field of activity. The actual amount of Belgian capital operating in Egypt can be estimated at 400,000 francs (roughly £st. 16,000), and this figure can be taken as somewhat under estimated. After having examined the situation. of these companies and contracts, Baron de Gaiffier turns his attention to the enlarging of the Port of Alexandria and the Egyptian rail- ways, and then reviews the foreign trade of Egypt, analysing the parts taken by the different countries as regards imports into Egypt. The countries which are to the greatest degree responsible for the increase in imports are. for 25,450,000 francs ,, 12,000,000 ,, 10,000,000
England France Belgium Germany Austro-Hungary "
Russia
America
t
Belgium for imports now takes sixth rank

just after Germany and before Italy and her share in the general trade of imports has risen from S.S. in 1905 to 5.1% in 1906. It is the country whose percentage has increased most rapidly and it is worthy of note that England's share as percentage in imports has hardly varied from one year to the other; in 1905 it was 32.3% and in 1906 32.7%.

In reviewing the principal imports we find that in some cases Belgium is practically mistress of the market, and in others she stands very high. The following are the imports mentioned in the report under review: Iron and worked steel, L.E. 362,659; Ironmongery, L.E. 168,589; Waggons, L.E. 163,168; Chemical manure, L.E 76,259; Cements, L.E. 60,855; Window-glass, L.E. 43,030; Sugar, L.E. 35,158 (as compared with L.E 87 in 1904); Flour, L.E. 28,151 (as compared with L.E. 87 in 1904; Linen fabrics, L.E. 27,674; Glasses and mirrors, L.E. 24,559; Locks and bolts, LE. 17,061; White zinc, L.E. 16,648; after which follow cast iron, glassware, arms, and chinaware, cotton fabrics, bronze and zinc, chemical products, electric apparatus, electric machines, cotton covers, colours, linen fabrics, hardware, and coal.

The Belgian Minister has not merely given a a succession of tables, he has supported them by a thorough study of the various heads of the statistical tables of the Egyptian Customs, profiting by the occasion to give invaluable information to Belgian exporters. We might cite as instances of this the following:-cotton fabrics, hosiery, metals and works in metal, automobiles, skins and works in skins, cereals, vegetables and flours, artificial indigo, chemical products, not to mention the principal imports. Such is enough to show the minute care with which this report has been drawn up, interesting as it is in its slightest details, and affording opportunity to the Belgian business man to follow the trade of his country with Egypt from one year to another.

Before concluding his exhortation to Belgians to increase still more their commercial activity in Egypt by the creation of new commercial establishments, Baron de Gaiffier gives good advice to Belgian merchants on the choice of representatives, the sending of travellers, catalogues, samples, and other methods of advertisement, credits, and also the important question of packing, which he says, should be as carefully done as if the goods were for China or Japan. This last is a very important point for it is often the making of a nation, for such and such an article, that the buyer receives it in perfect good order and ready to be sold or used immediately.
CHARLES RUELEUS.
Licencié en Sciences Commerciales et Consulaires. Boursier.
Commercial du Gouvernement Belge en
Egypt.

div.head: BANKING BRITISH AND FRENCH.
div.p: A CONTRAST.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, -For our French neighbours is frequently claimed the premier position among the world's bankers, but I hardly think that an examination of their banking system and a comparison with that of the British banks will sustain this claim. Last week you published the monthly statement of the National Bank of Egypt Ltd., for August, and Wednesday you published the statement of the Crédit Lyonnais for the same month. Now I propose to compare these two statements with the statement of eight of the leading English Banks for August as supplied by the "Economist" of the 14th ulto.
The following are the more important figures: the total liabilities in each case including the amount due to Shareholders in respect of capital and reserves.
Total Cash on hand and at Liabilities Bank of Eng. &c.
L.
Capital and Counties....
Lloyds..
London & S. Western..
London & Westminster
The Lond. City & Midland.. National
National Provincial of Eng. Union of London & Smiths.
Percent- 6.377.856 age to liabilities
National Bank of Egypt Ld...
Credit Lyonnais (on the basis of frá. 25 to £1) In addition to the cash on hand the

English banks hold a further amount at call and short notice equal to 10% of their liabilities; which is slightly more than the amount of the Capital Reserve of about 34 1/2 millions. It therefore appears that either the English Banks and the National Bank of Egypt Ltd., ǎre too conservative of their gold resources or that the reserve of the Credit Lyonnais is insufficient. Of course I shall be told that the latter institution has always the Bank of France to resort to in case of need: but that fact in nowise invalidates my argument in favour of the methods of British, banking. am, Sir,
I
Yours Truly. Q. E. D. Alexandria, 11th October.

div.head: PILGRIMS AND QUARANTINE.
div.p: The following notice to agents of pilgrim ships has been issued by H.B.M's. Consul General Gould -A telegram has been received by H.B.M's Agency, Cairo, from Constantinople to the effect that pilgrim ships which left before October 1 will be exempt from the strict application of regulations respecting payment of quarantine dues by captains, and delay till November 1st granted for complying with artiole 24 respecting disinfection stoue.

div.head: CAIRO TO HELOUAN.
div.p: A HIGHWAY WANTED.

One of the greatest wants in Egypt is that r of highways. Alexandria and Cairo have been s waiting for years for road connection and yet t that much felt want seems as far off as ever. s The most extraordinary need in regard to a communication is that between Cairo and J Helouan. In the case of Alexandria the Govern-S ment might plead that the one hundred and thirty miles of intervening space through the richest agricultural district in the world would necessitate an enormous amount of most costly expropriations. But, in the case of Helouan and Cairo the question of communication by road is on an entirely different footing. For a great part of the way the road would be over the desert. Furthermore this suburb is only seventeen miles from Cairo. Helouan is the most unique suburb of Cairo from the point of view of desert air, but if a road existed this world-famed health resort would be popularised a thousandfold. It is well-t known that the sulphur springs are the second strongest in the world. From its situation overlooking the Nile and the wonderful Pyramids of Sakkara and Darshur it is a delightful point for excursions. It is one hundred feet over the Nile flood level and is beautifully situated for excursions to the mountains of the Arabian desert and such exquisite bits of scenery as the wonderful Wady Hof. Yet in spite of all these actractions no motorist can make his way thither from Cairo, and Helouan up to now is soley dependent on its line of railway. Surely the Government ought to consider this claim of Cairo's favourite suburb to the necessary expenditure for a high road to unite it with Cairo.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limitsfree discussion.

div.head: CAIRO'S DRAINAGE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE "

Sir, With the return of the eminent Anglo-Indian specialist, Mr. Carkeet James, to Cairo and with the immediate advent of Sir William Garstin to Europe next week, the question of the final settlement of the site ne- cessary for the Cairo sewage work has once again come forward. The subject is of vital importance to many land development companies, besides private individuals, who have the building of their own houses in view. From what one can gather it would appear that the two sites mostly in favour are those actually situated to the north and south of the city. These chosen spots are Khanka and Tourah. In view of the fact that Rod el Farag, where the wells of the water supply are situated, is on the north, it is impossible to have the sewage overflow thereabouts. Surely in a city of this sort, where in summer the wind always blows from the north, one could assume that a southern site was absolutely necessary to the health of the public. No doubt the authorities have been considering all these points and it is sincerely to be hoped that they will at last cease from their extraordinary policy of silence and take the public into their confidence.
Truly Yours
Cairo, 11th October.
SANITAS.

div.head: PRINCE DABRO.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Dear Sir.
In your yesterday's issue I found a few lines about the Khedive's heir, a certain Prince Dabro in Texas.

I beg to inform you that Dabro is the family name of late Dicran Pasha, The Dabros descend from an ancient family of rulers. Hence the title of Prince. The regretted Pasha did not make use of the title of Prince, most probably for political reasons. But his brother and son are called Princes. The son, the Prince Aram Dabro is well known in Cairo. He is a big land owner. It is quite possible that he visits the United States to study the cotton industry.

New York journalists finding the name of a Prince in a high class hotel visitors' list, run to have an interview. Naturally His Highness tells them that he has come to see how the Americans cultivate the cotton, the most important production of Egyptian soil. The journalists thinking that this is not worthy of a Prince from the land of Pharoahs add the
rest.

Imagination is very rife in some newspaper correspondents, on both sides of the Atlantic. See, what some English papers said about His. Excellency Boghos Pasha Nubar, a few weeks ago. His Excellency could never think of uld never thin telling any man that, he owns the Egyptian Railways. With all that it was repeated in several papers. Why not inquire from a reliable source.
Yours Respectfully,
Cairo, October 11.
ONLOOKER.

div.p: EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Probably the life of the Emperor of Austria is of greater importance to the peace of Europe than that of any other living ruler and the news of his present indisposition will be a source of grave disquietude. This morning's telegram is a little more reassuring, but considering that he is seventy-six years of age the slightest indisposition is dangerous. Francis Joseph I was born on August 18th, 1830, at Schönbrunn, where he is now lying ill.
Mustapha Pasha Fahmy, will arrive at Alexandria next Tuesday.
Sir Eldon Gorst came to Alexandria yester day and presented Mr. Paul Harvey to the Khedive. He returned to Cairo the same evening.
Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha inspected the Alexandria Egyptian garrison at Ras el Tin this morning. The Sirdar was also received in private audience this morning by the Khedive.

Sir Vincent Corbett bade farewell yesterday to the officials of the Finance Ministry and charged them with a message to the employés th a mess expressing his regret that he had been unable to remain to carry out his scheme for improving their position.
The "Official Journal" has published the decree whereby Mr. Henry Paul Harvey is appointed Financial Adviser to the Egyptian Government, to date from the 9th inst.
Mansfield Pasha is due on Monday by the Austrian Lloyd mail boat.
Count and Countess Bernstorff and Miss Bernstorff are due to arrive on the 28th inst. by the S.S. "Schleswig." the S.S.
Baron de Runcker Jenisch, ex German Minister in Egypt, has been appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs to the German Government.
The Sultan has conferred the first grade of Iftikhar and of Roumalli Bekla Bey on Meisner Pasha, chief engineer of the Hedjaz railway..
Miralai Dixon Bey, Director of the Blue Nile, has arrived in Cairo from his holidays, and will spend a few days there prior to his departure to the Sudan.
Colonel E. A. Herbert, M.V.O. Inniskilling Dragoons, and Captain B. B. Bartlett, A.V.D., are leaving for Syria on Friday next on remount duty.
The Rev. Father Godfrey has been appointed acting chaplain to the Roman Catholic troops at Kasr el Nil, Cairo.
Suleiman el Bustani, the noted Egyptian poet, has returned from the Lebanon, where he has spent the summer.

Amongst the visitors staying at the Hotel Beau Rivage we notice: Mr. G. H. Napiar; Mr. E. Klein; Mr. H. E. Mann; Mr.. E. V. Wellings; Miss Meta Deicks; Mr. Rudolf Priets; Mr. L. Limpritis; Mr. L. Simpson; Mr. A. Whyte; Miss Ottilie Heller; Miss Minna Thorn; Miss Filo Agopian; Mrs. D. Ireland; Mrs. Craig and family; Mr. James Watson; Mr. and Mrs. Diamant and Mrs. M. Lamper.

div.head: THE CAIRO STREETS.
div.p: A letter appears to-day in the columns of a contemporary, calling attention to the state of the roads in Cairo. Such complaints, which are unfortunately fully justified by the existing state of a large number of the streets, are frequent enough, but up to the present time apparently no effort has been made by the authorities to remedy the cause. The main thoroughfares, for the most part, leave nothing to be desired, but once depart from these roads and one might as well be in the heart of the country where the tanzim is unknown. There are some streets in the Cairo of to-day which are, by reason of their filth, unfit for a pedestrian to use, while should he essay to cycle through them, the result would be disastrous both to machine and rider. Rough and uneven, malodorous and filthy, they remain from year to year a blot on the boasted civilization of Cairo. One cannot believe that it is ignorance which causes the tanzim to continue their policy of playing with the question, instead of striking at the root of the evil and putting competent men to the work of re-laying the roads on an approved modern system. And yet if it is not ignorance, what is it ?

Is it due to lack of funds or to lack of men, or simply to lack of thought? But whatever the reason, the fact remains that certain of the streets of Cairo are a disgrace to the town, that the time has come when it is a matter of necessity that something should be done, and that a long suffering public expects it to be done at once.
THE
Hotel Casino San Stefano Will be open during Winter.
REDUCED PRIC
